step.context: \text{If the vector cross product }\vec{b}\times\vec{a}=\vec{c}, \\ \text{are the following true about $\vec{c}$ ?}
step.tex: \text{$\vec{c}$ is $\perp$ to the plane containing $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$.}
\text{$\vec{c}$ lies in the plane containing $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$.}
step.reason: \text{As suggested by the Right-Hand rule, the} \\ \text{cross-product of two non-zero vectors is}\\ \text{a vector which is perpendicular to the plane} \\ \text{containing the original two vectors.}

step.context: \vec{c}=(\vec{b}\times\vec{a}) \text{. If $\vec{c}\perp\vec{a}$, what can we say about} \\ \vec{a}\cdot\vec{c}?
